import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)

# Input data files are available in the "../input/" directory.

        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

source.68c1d7ca:
nRowsRead = 1000 # specify 'None' if want to read whole file
df = pd.read_csv('../input/cusersmarildownloadshightechcsv/hightech.csv', delimiter=';', encoding = "ISO-8859-1", nrows = nRowsRead)
df.dataframeName = 'hightech.csv'
nRow, nCol = df.shape
print(f'There are {nRow} rows and {nCol} columns')
source.87ca0bd9: print("That's our Kaggle Bot. My inseparable team mate")
source.7b985f9f:
#Missing values. Codes from my friend Caesar Lupum @caesarlupum
total = df.isnull().sum().sort_values(ascending = False)
percent = (df.isnull().sum()/df.isnull().count()*100).sort_values(ascending = False)
missing_data  = pd.concat([total, percent], axis=1, keys=['Total', 'Percent'])
missing_data.head(8)
source.40545939:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
source.8b805425:
import plotly.offline as pyo
import plotly.graph_objs as go
lowerdf = df.groupby('year').size()/df['proportion'].count()*100
labels = lowerdf.index
values = lowerdf.values

# Use `hole` to create a donut-like pie chart
fig = go.Figure(data=[go.Pie(labels=labels, values=values, hole=.6)])
fig.show()
source.a1349de3:
ng = df[df.proportion <250]
plt.figure(figsize=(8,4))
sns.boxplot(y="proportion",x ='year' ,data = ng)
plt.title("proportion & year < 250")
plt.xticks(rotation=45)
plt.show()
source.297ec695:
#catplot room type and price
plt.figure(figsize=(10,6))
sns.catplot(x="year", y="proportion", data=df);
plt.xticks(rotation=90)
plt.ioff()

f, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(8,6))
x = df['proportion']
ax = sns.distplot(x, bins=10)
plt.show()

f, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(8,6))

ax = sns.kdeplot(x)
plt.show()

plt.show()

plt.show()

sns.stripplot(x="year", y="proportion", hue="proportion", 
                   data=df, palette="Set2", size=20, marker="D",
                   edgecolor="gray", alpha=.25)
plt.xticks(rotation=45)
plt.show()

source.0727fc83:

g = g.map_diag(plt.hist)
g = g.map_offdiag(plt.scatter)
g = g.add_legend()
source.f94d6d38:
g = sns.PairGrid(datt)
g = g.map_upper(plt.scatter)
g = g.map_lower(sns.kdeplot, cmap="Blues_d")
g = g.map_diag(sns.kdeplot, lw=3, legend=False)
source.847a319f:
g = sns.JointGrid(x="year", y="proportion", data=df)
g = g.plot(sns.regplot, sns.distplot)
source.27154b79:
g = sns.JointGrid(x="year", y="proportion", data=df, space=0)
g = g.plot_joint(sns.kdeplot, cmap="Blues_d")
g = g.plot_marginals(sns.kdeplot, shade=True)
source.e0908bf0:
g = sns.JointGrid(x="year", y="proportion", data=df, height=5, ratio=2)
g = g.plot_joint(sns.kdeplot, cmap="Reds_d")
g = g.plot_marginals(sns.kdeplot, color="r", shade=True)

source.e4d7e658:
High technology, or high tech (sometimes also called frontier technology or frontier tech), is technology that is at the cutting edge: the most advanced technology available.
***Cortright, Joseph; Mayer, Heike (January 2001). High Tech Specialization: A Comparison of High Technology Centers (PDF). Brookings Institution, Center on Urban & Metropolitan Policy.
